attributes.title: A Home for your open source project

blurb.html:
You did it! The open source project you launched a couple of years ago has picked-up steam. At first, only a few developers tried it out, but soon more developers joined them, companies followed in their path, and you now even have a number of large tech companies using it. As a result, you‚Äôre receiving a steady stream of bug reports and, increasingly, pull requests from contributors all over the world. Your project has a community. It‚Äôs healthy. It‚Äôs growing.

So far, you‚Äôve been the one setting the project‚Äôs direction, but you‚Äôre well aware this won‚Äôt continue working for long. You need to bring in more people to help maintain the project, and naturally they‚Äôll want a say in how it moves forward. You‚Äôve also heard from other large corporations who‚Äôd be interested to contribute to the project or use it, but require a more open governance model to be able to fully commit.

The next steps are obvious; you need to move the project to a software foundation.

But which one should you pick and why?

In this talk, we‚Äôll look at why you‚Äôd want to move a project to a foundation, and what doing so involves. We‚Äôll give you a solid rundown of the various foundations and related options, and their pros and cons. And we‚Äôll arm you with enough knowledge so you can ask the right question and make the best decision for your project.

desc.html: üè° A home for your open source project Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üó∫ First, some context Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

üó∫ Why this topic? ‚óè Recent consulting work to bring the AMP project to the OpenJS Foundation. ‚óè Advised Coil on setting up the Interledger Foundation. ‚óè Pro bono analysis to set W3C‚Äôs headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland. ‚óè Currently working on creating another software foundation in Geneva. ‚óè OASIS Open Projects Advisory Council member. ‚óè OpenJSF Cross Project Council member. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üè° What is it & what is it for? Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

üè° What‚Äôs a foundation and what is it for? A foundation provides a legal entity for open source projects. It can: ‚óè receive and spend money (e.g. infra costs, travel expenses), ‚óè acquire and own assets (e.g. trademarks), ‚óè grant and receive licenses (e.g. copyright, patents), ‚óè hire people (e.g. for a security audit, coaching, etc.), ‚óè host events, ‚óè etc. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
ü§î ‚ÄúWait, do I need this?‚Äù Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
ü§î If you‚Äôre wondering about this‚Ä¶ Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üö´ ‚Ä¶you probably don‚Äôt! Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üëâüö™ Now‚Äôs the right time to leave. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
‚è± Timing is critical Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚è± When should you move? Timing is critical. You‚Äôre always better off moving too late than too early! ‚óè Wait until you experience growing pains & those can be solved by a foundation. ‚óè What are good examples of issues that a foundation helps with? ‚óã Operational issues ‚óã Trust ‚óã Community ownership ‚óã Creating a level-playing field ‚óã Etc. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚è± When should you move? Timing is critical. You‚Äôre always better off moving too late than too early! ‚óè Wait until you experience growing pains & those can be solved by a foundation. ‚óè What are good examples of issues that a foundation helps with? ‚óã Operational issues ‚óã Trust ‚óã Community ownership ‚óã Creating a level-playing field Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚è± üß≥ Covering travel expenses of AMP TSC/AC members required fragile workarounds. üîê Data protection requirements added hurdles to the community-driven organization of the AMP Contributor Summit. ‚úç CLA assigned the license to Google. This was a deterrent for many AMP contributors. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚è± When should you move? Timing is critical. You‚Äôre always better off moving too late than too early! ‚óè Wait until you experience growing pains & those can be solved by a foundation. ‚óè What are good examples of issues that a foundation helps with? ‚óã Operational issues ‚óã Trust ‚óã Community ownership ‚óã Creating a level-playing field Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚è± When should you move? Timing is critical. You‚Äôre always better off moving too late than too early! ‚óè Wait until you experience growing pains & those can be solved by a foundation. ‚óè What are good examples of issues that a foundation helps with? ‚óã Operational issues ‚óã Trust ‚óã Community ownership ‚óã Creating a level-playing field Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚è± When should you move? Timing is critical. You‚Äôre always better off moving too late than too early! ‚óè Wait until you experience growing pains & those can be solved by a foundation. ‚óè What are good examples of issues that a foundation helps with? ‚óã Operational issues ‚óã Trust ‚óã Community ownership ‚óã Creating a level-playing field Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚è± Why move as late as possible? ‚óè A foundation adds overhead. ‚óè A foundation costs money. ‚óè You can start by creating an open governance model without a legal entity. ‚û¢ That‚Äôs what we did for AMP! Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
‚è± Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üëç So you‚Äôve determined that this is‚Äîin fact‚Äîfor you. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üèò Plenty of options Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

üèò Foundations come in all shapes and forms Yearly revenue (2017 or 2018*) Status Apache Software Foundation $2,583,535 501(c)(3) Free Software Foundation (FSF) $3,663,026 501(c)(3) $96,582,653 501(c)(6) $555,610 501(c)(3) $2,999,466 501(c)(3) Linux Foundation* Open Source Initiative (OSI)* Software Freedom Conservancy Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üèò üåé And that‚Äôs in the US only‚Ä¶ Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üèò üåè Most jurisdictions have equivalent legal structures. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üèò üåç Switzerland‚Äôs are both lightweight & flexible. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

üèò Foundations come in all shapes and forms ‚óè Join an existing foundation. ‚óè Foundation within a foundation. ‚óè Foundation as a Service. ‚óè Roll your own. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

üèò Join an existing foundation The project is one of many other projects handled by the foundation. Example: a project joining either of the Apache Software Foundation (ASF), the Software Freedom Conservancy, OASIS Open Projects, or the OpenJS Foundation. PROS CONS ‚úÖ Lightweight. ‚ùå Not very flexible (works for you or doesn‚Äôt). ‚úÖ Cheap and fast to set up. ‚ùå Often limited in what it does (e.g. just IP). ‚úÖ Little to no maintenance overhead. ‚ùå Lack of independence. ‚úÖ Generally no membership fees (funded through sponsorship). Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

üèò Foundation within a foundation The foundation is a spinoff of the parent foundation. Legally, it‚Äôs still the same entity. This is an Increasingly common model favored by the Linux Foundation. Examples: Cloud Native Computing Foundation, LF Edge Foundation, Hyperledger, GraphQL, etc. PROS ‚úÖ Can be heavily customized. ‚úÖ Still cheap and fast to set up. CONS ‚ùå Often requires members to pay membership fees to both the foundation itself and its parent foundation. ‚ùå No really independent from the parent foundation. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

üèò Foundation as a Service The foundation is an independent organization that purchases services (accounting, tax filing, legal, etc.) from a separate entity focused on serving foundations. Examples: Open Mobility Foundation, the OpenJS Foundation itself, OASIS Foundation-as-a-Service, etc. PROS CONS ‚úÖ Completely customizable. ‚ùå Complex and potentially costly to set up. ‚úÖ Very much independent (the foundation is only purchasing a service). ‚ùå Significant maintenance overhead. ‚úÖ Benefits from the economies of scale of its service provider. ‚úÖ Free to set up its own membership solution. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

üèò Roll your own Build everything from scratch. No one does this anymore. Examples: Linux Foundation (LF), Free Software Foundation (FSF), etc. PROS ‚úÖ Design exactly what you want: the sky‚Äôs the limit. CONS ‚ùå Prohibitively expensive. ‚ùå Complex and long to set up. ‚ùå No economies of scale. ‚ùå High maintenance cost. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üèò Cheap & Easy üèï üè° Rigid Flexible üèñ üè∞ Expensive & Complicated Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
Join existing foundation üèò Cheap & Easy Foundation within a foundation Rigid Flexible Done for you model Roll your own Expensive & Complicated Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üèò ‚öñ No perfect solution. Always a tradeoff. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üèò üóú So which one is a good fit for you? Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üèò ü§∑ Well‚Ä¶ it depends! Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
‚úÖ Define your goals & requirements Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚úÖ Goals & requirements ‚óè Goals must be representatives of the needs of your stakeholders. ‚óè Have reasonable goals. ‚û¢ You can‚Äôt aim for a CNCF-like structure with a 50K yearly budget. ‚óè Turn goals into requirements. ‚óè Requirements will steer you towards a type of solution (from joining an existing solution to rolling your own). ‚óè Requirements will help you reduce the size of your option pool quickly. ‚û¢ For example, the ASF was not an option for AMP because of its requirements around tooling. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚úÖ Change Pay attention to change. üí° We tend to imagine this space as rigid and fixed. It‚Äôs not. It‚Äôs evolving all the time. ‚óè There are new structures being created as new languages, projects, verticals, etc. gain traction. ‚óè Existing structures change. ‚û¢ ‚óè There are mergers, spinoffs, etc. ‚û¢ ‚óè E.g. the ASF is now loosening it tooling requirements. E.g. FINOS joining the LF. Look around, maybe you can join forces with like-minded projects or individuals. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚úÖ Seize opportunities Pay attention to opportunities and seize them. ‚óè The OpenJSF was just getting announced when AMP started looking. ‚óè Joining early allowed AMP to help shape the foundation significantly. ‚óè As a result, we ended up with much of the flexibility that was needed with little of the cost. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
Join existing foundation ‚úÖ Cheap & Easy Foundation within a foundation Rigid Flexible Done for you model Roll your own Expensive & Complicated Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚úÖ Focus ‚óè Don‚Äôt get distracted by bells and whistles. ‚óè E.g. If you‚Äôre not interested in throwing events, the foundation‚Äôs capability of doing so isn‚Äôt really useful to you. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen

‚úÖ Learn from others ‚óè A lot of people have been there before, talk to them. ‚óè Great to avoid common pitfalls. ‚óè Contextualize advice for your particular context. ‚óè ‚û¢ The lay of the land has probably changed since then. ‚û¢ They had different needs and so made different tradeoffs. Get help if this is mission critical. ‚û¢ A bit self-serving, but I‚Äôm sure my clients agree. Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üôè Thank you! Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
üé§ Q&A Tobie Langel (@tobie) Principal, UnlockOpen
